docs.lead_paragraph: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Day Care: Vote on an amendment to the Pentagon's $270 billion budget for the 1999 fiscal year that would provide $270 million to expand day care at military bases. Rejected 74 to 18, June 25. 2. Base Closings: Vote on an amendment to the Pentagon's $270 billion budget for the 1999 fiscal year that would make it harder for the Clinton Administration to shut more bases. Approved 48 to 45, June 25. 3. Abortions: Vote on an amendment to the Pentagon's $270 billion budget for the 1999 fiscal year that would lift a ban on military women or the wives of servicemen obtaining abortions in military hospitals. Rejected 49 to 44, June 25. 1 2 3 Connecticut Dodd (D) Nay Yea Yea Lieberman (D) Nay Nay Yea New Jersey Lautenberg (D) Yea Yea Yea Torricelli (D) Yea Yea Yea New York D'Amato (R) Nay Yea Nay Moynihan (D) Nay Nay Yea House 1. Abortions: Vote on an amendment to a bill appropriating $56 billion for the Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration for the 1999 fiscal Year that would prohibit the Food and Drug Administration from using taxpayer money to test, develop or approve any drug for the chemical inducement of abortion. Approved 223 to 202, June 24. 2. Appropriation: Procedural vote to begin considering a bill appropriating money for the Treasury Department and Postal Service for the 1999 fiscal Year. The bill is controversial because it contains a provision that would require all health-insurance plans for Federal employees cover the full range of contraceptives that they offer for other prescription drugs and it does not provide money to prepare the Government to cope with the computer glitch expected in the Year 2000. Rejected 291 to 125, June 25. 1 2 Connecticut 1. Kennelly (D) Nay Yea 2. Gejdenson (D) Nay Yea 3. DeLauro (D) Nay Nay 4. Shays (R) Nay Yea 5. Maloney (D) Nay Nay 6. Johnson (R) Nay Yea New Jersey 1. McCarthy (D) Nay Nay 5. Ackerman (D) Nay Yea 6. Meeks (D) Nay Nay 7. Manton (D) Yea Nay 8. Nadler (D) Nay Nay 9. Schumer (D) Nay Yea 10. Towns (D) Nay Nay 11. Owens (D) Nay Nay 12. Velazquez (D) Nay Yea 13. Fossella (R) Yea Nay 14. Maloney (D) Nay Nay 15. Rangel (D) Nay Nay 16. Serrano (D) Nay Nay 17. Engel (D) Nay Yea 18. Lowey (D) Nay Yea 19. Kelly (R) Nay Yea 20. Gilman (R) Nay Yea 21. McNulty (D) Yea Nay 22. Solomon (R) Yea Yea 23. Boehlert (R) Nay Yea 24. McHugh (R) Yea Nay 25. Walsh (R) Yea Nay 26. Hinchey (D) Nay Nay 27. Paxon (R) Yea Yea 28. docs.lead_paragraph: ANNY DeGANGE HOLGATE and her husband, Ron, call their apartment at 250 Cabrini Boulevard ''our gift from the universe.'' ''If everybody gets one gift in life, this was it,'' Ms. Holgate said while walking through the brightly lit two-bedroom apartment. It is a pretty place, with views east toward the Whitestone Bridge, but the gift she refers to was the price: $10,000.

headline.main: Habitats/250 Cabrini Boulevard, Washington Heights; Breaking a Leg Uptown: 5-Room Co-op for $10,000

docs.abstract: Anny DeGange Holgate and her husband, Ron, both actors, describe how they were able to buy 5-room co-op at 250 Cabrini Boulevard in upper Manhattan for only $10,000; co-op's sponsor had gone bankrupt; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 221st session of the New York State Legislature ground to a close at 6:02 P.M. on June 19, not with the usual lofty declarations of achievement and unity, but with a general acknowledgment by lawmakers that, in an election year of partisan attacks and personal animus, many important issues were left unaddressed. There were, in essence, two sessions. The first began with modest agendas but fairly high hopes, and culminated in April along with the Legislature's budget negotiations, conducted in public for the first time, and the earliest passage of a budget in five years.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions of the 221st Session of the Legislature

docs.abstract: Summary of major actions taken by New York State Legislature during its 221st session; photo (M)

byline.original: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

docs.lead_paragraph: Some big health insurers are putting a new squeeze on doctors, sharply cutting the fees they pay and imposing strict new rules that physicians say can undermine patient care. Angry doctors, in turn, are fighting back with lawsuits and complaints to state regulators. Many traditional health plans and physician networks have for several years been relatively generous to doctors, giving them something close to the ''usual and customary fees'' in a community.

headline.main: INSURERS TIGHTEN RULES AND REDUCE FEES FOR DOCTORS

docs.abstract: Big health insurers are sharply cutting fees they pay doctors and imposing strict new rules; angry doctors say this can undermine patient care, and they are fighting back with lawsuits and complaints to state regulators; many traditional health plans and physician networks have in past been relatively generous, hoping to persuade doctors to join their networks; insurers soon felt caught between big employers that resisted rate increases and doctors and hospitals that joined forces to strengthen their bargaining power; latest cuts, along with efforts to raise rates significantly for some employers, can be seen as effort to try to restore profits by regaining control; if doctors balk at any restrictions, they can be blackballed from plans, losing access to thousands of patients; even though insurers have final say over whether treatment is necessary, many contracts hold doctors, not health plans, liable in malpractice suits over denial of care; doctors say most aggressive insurers clamping down are Aetna US Healthcare, Blue Cross plans in seven states, and local units of United Healthcare and Cigna Healthcare; chart (L)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: They gritted their teeth, but on Wednesday, with their health-care gurus lined up shoulder to shoulder, House Republicans unveiled their plan to patch up managed care with such measures as expanding a patient's ability to choose a doctor and to receive emergency care. But as they did, they raised an important question: Did Republican leaders offer the plan simply to provide political cover for the November elections, or are they genuinely trying to pass a law to address patients' concerns?
docs.abstract: Analysis of House Republican approach to patching up managed health care; plan may be aimed at addressing both political and patient concerns; House Republicans have not worked with Senate counterparts on issue and Senators are resisting being rushed; House Republicans were careful not to make proposal too palatable to Democrats, whose support may be needed for Senate passage; Rep Charlie Norwood, Republican who ignored his leaders' earlier opposition to bill, questions tactic and calls for bipartisan law; photo (M)/

docs.lead_paragraph: Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest and weakest financial institutions, is in negotiations to merge with a smaller, stronger rival, a move that could turn the combined bank into a showcase for the Government's first blueprint to clean up the nation's bad debt. If Long-Term's talks with the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company succeed, it would create a bank with $316 billion in assets, slightly behind the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the biggest bank in the United States with $364.7 billion in assets. It could also end weeks of worries that financial troubles at Long-Term could spread and endanger financial stability in Japan, which is already suffering from its worst postwar economic performance, a weakening currency and a jittery stock market.

headline.main: Japan Waits As 2 Banks Weigh Merger

docs.abstract: Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest and weakest banks, discusses merger with smaller, stronger rival, Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co, move that could ease concerns that troubles at Long-Term could spread and endanger Japan's financial stability; Liberal Democratic Party secretary general, Koichi Kato, hails talks; denies party leaders helped broker deal, which would give Government chance to put into practice its blueprint for tackling $600 billion in bad debt held by banks; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto orders detailed plan for establishment of bridge bank to assume loans and clients of failed institution (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Another day, another dozen deals. On a single day last month, Office Depot, an eye on expanding abroad, agreed to buy Viking Office Products in a $3 billion stock swap; Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company announced a $1.59 billion hostile tender offer for Allied Group, an Iowa car and home insurer; Dillard's, the Midwestern retailer, bought the Mercantile Stores Company for $2.9 billion, and Cardinal Health, hoping to become a one-stop service provider for pharmaceutical companies, paid $2.2 billion in stock for R. P. Scherer. And those were just the biggest fish. In all, 11 proposed deals with a total value of about $17 billion were announced on May 18. It was a pace almost unheard of -- or would have been last year or the year before. In 1998, though, it wasn't so unusual. The growing conviction by corporations worldwide that bigger is better in the global marketplace has generated a merger wave that has dwarfed anything that preceded it.

headline.main: Magnetic Mania; In This Merged, Merged World, Anything Goes

docs.lead_paragraph: In a surprise slap at Republican leaders, the House Appropriations Committee voted today in favor of financing the National Endowment for the Arts. The vote, 31 to 27, reversed a subcommittee's denial of money to the endowment just last week.

headline.main: In Surprise Rebuff to G.O.P. Chiefs, House Panel Backs Money for Arts Endowment
headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: THE FEDERAL AGENCY

docs.snippet: In a surprise slap at Republican leaders, the House Appropriations Committee voted today in favor of financing the National Endowment for the Arts.    The vote, 31 to 27, reversed a subcommittee's denial of money to the endowment just last week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court ruling that people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, are protected from discrimination under the Americans With Disabilities Act even if they suffer no symptoms of AIDS. The opinion, Randon Bragdon v. Sidney Abbott, was written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy and joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. A dissenting opinion was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and joined by Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, and Sandra Day O'Connor. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Kennedy Respondent Sidney Abbott has been infected with H.I.V. since 1986. When the incidents we recite occurred, her infection had not manifested its most serious symptoms. On Sept. 16, 1994, she went to the office of petitioner Randon Bragdon in Bangor, Me., for a dental appointment. She disclosed her H.I.V. infection on the patient registration form.

headline.main: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinion on H.I.V. Infection as a Disability

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution prohibited the President from rewriting legislation by vetoing single items of spending or specific tax breaks approved by Congress. In a 6-to-3 decision, the Court rejected a decades-old effort to strengthen the hand of the President in struggles with Congress.

headline.main: SEE H.I.V. AS DISABILITY; SPENDING AT ISSUE
headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: THE OPINION -- JUSTICES, 6-3, BAR VETO OF LINE ITEMS IN BILLS
